mainmatter.p:
Let \mathbb{C} and \mathbb{D} be two categories. An adjunction between \mathbb{C} and \mathbb{D} consists of functors F : \mathbb{C} \to \mathbb{D} and U : \mathbb{D} \to \mathbb{C} equipped with a natural transformation \eta : \mathbf{1} _{ \mathbb{C} } \to U \circ F such that
for any C \in \mathbb{C} , D \in \mathbb{D} and any \mathbb{C}-morphism f : C \to U(D), there exists a \mathbb{D}-morphism g : F(C) \to D unique with the property of making the following diagram commute:
Definition 9.1 from Steve Awodey's book on category theory.

frontmatter.title: Category Theory
frontmatter.meta: @book{awodey-ct-book, title = {Category Theory}, author = {Awodey, Steve}, date = {2010}, address = {Great Clarendon Street, Oxford, {OX2 6DP}}, edition = {2}, isbn = {978-0-19-923718-0}, publisher = {Oxford University Press}, series = {Oxford Logic Guides}, volume = {52}, }

mainmatter.p:
Let \mathbb{C} and \mathbb{D} be two categories. An adjunction between \mathbb{C} and \mathbb{D} consists of functors F : \mathbb{C} \to \mathbb{D} and U : \mathbb{D} \to \mathbb{C} equipped with a natural transformation \eta : \mathbf{1} _{ \mathbb{C} } \to U \circ F such that
for any C \in \mathbb{C} , D \in \mathbb{D} and any \mathbb{C}-morphism f : C \to U(D), there exists a \mathbb{D}-morphism g : F(C) \to D unique with the property of making the following diagram commute:
Definition 9.1 from Steve Awodey's book on category theory.
